description: The round payoff this round was 5. You, John chose to play option 1.Kate chose to play option 1. You received a payoff of 0.

The game is a coordination dilemma: Both players have the safe option (option 1) yielding a neutral payoff (0), and a risky option (option 2) that could give a positive payoff equal to the round input (here, 5) if only one deviates—but if both choose it, the punishment is enormous (5 × 1000).

In the observed round, both John and Kate chose option 1, which implies that they possibly prioritized avoiding the risk of mutual deviation; even though the round input was positive (5) and a unilateral switch to option 2 would have yielded a gain, the fear of triggering a catastrophic loss (5 × 1000) made safe play more attractive.

This memory may influence future strategy decisions—John might consider the trust and risk dynamics: if there’s confidence that Kate (or vice versa) will stick with the safe option, there may be an incentive to deviate for a marginal gain, yet the potential for mutual deviation (and thus massive losses) suggests caution.
